summary.text_en: Archimedes's greatest mathematical achievement was his mastery of infinitesimals. He perfected the 'Method of Exhaustion' (a rigorous form of limits) and used a 'Mechanical Method' to discover new theorems. He famously calculated the first rigorous value of Pi (Ï€) and found the areas and volumes of spheres, cylinders, and parabolasâ€”achievements not surpassed until the invention of calculus by Newton and Leibniz 1,800 years later.

story.text_en: Archimedes's treatises, like 'On the Sphere and Cylinder' and 'Quadrature of the Parabola', are monuments of human thought. He 'squeezed' the value of Pi by inscribing and circumscribing circles with polygons of up to 96 sides. His proudest discovery was the 2/3 relationship between a sphere and its circumscribing cylinder. He considered this so important that he asked for the diagram to be placed on his tombstone.

fun_facts.text_en: Archimedes's proudest achievement was his proof that a sphere's volume is 2/3 that of its circumscribing cylinder. He requested this diagram be engraved on his tomb. Over 100 years later, the Roman statesman Cicero claimed to have found this forgotten tomb in the ruins of Syracuse.

When Roman soldiers stormed Syracuse in 212 BC, one found Archimedes studying a geometry problem in the sand. He allegedly said, 'Do not disturb my circles!' (NÅlÄ« turbÄre circulus meÅs!) and was killed.

simple_explanation.text_en: How do you measure the area of a circle? This was a huge problem. Archimedes had a genius idea: He drew a square *inside* the circle (whose area he could calculate) and a square *outside* the circle. The circle's area was somewhere between them. Then he did it again with a pentagon... then a hexagon... all the way up to a 96-sided polygon! The 96-sided shape was *almost* a circle, and by calculating its area, he got an incredibly precise value for the circle's area and for Pi. This idea of 'getting infinitely close' is the core idea of calculus.

applications.text_en: His ability to calculate the area and volume of parabolas (like in an arch bridge) and spheres (like a dome) was critical for engineering.

impact.text_en: Archimedes brought Greek mathematics to its absolute zenith. His rigorous handling of the infinite and infinitesimals was astonishingly close to modern integration. Had his work 'The Method' not been lost during the Middle Ages, the Scientific Revolution might have occurred centuries earlier.

options_en: The Method of Exhaustion (using inscribed and circumscribed polygons)
quiz.explanation_en: He 'squeezed' the value of Pi by inscribing and circumscribing a circle with polygons of an increasing number of sides (up to 96), 'exhausting' the area and circumference to trap Pi within a very narrow range.
